detaileddescription.para: Common Timer_control command code reservation offset. Timer driver implementations should offset command codes with Timer_CMD_RESERVED growing positively
Example implementation specific command codes: #defineTimerXYZ_CMD_COMMAND0Timer_CMD_RESERVED+0 #defineTimerXYZ_CMD_COMMAND1Timer_CMD_RESERVED+1
Common Timer_control status code reservation offset. Timer driver implementations should offset status codes with Timer_STATUS_RESERVED growing negatively.
Example implementation specific status codes: #defineTimerXYZ_STATUS_ERROR0Timer_STATUS_RESERVED-0 #defineTimerXYZ_STATUS_ERROR1Timer_STATUS_RESERVED-1

briefdescription.para: Successful status code.
Generic error status code.
An error status code returned by Timer_control() for undefined command codes.

detaileddescription.para: Timer_control() returns Timer_STATUS_UNDEFINEDCMD if the control code is not recognized by the driver implementation.

Is a non-blocking call. After Timer_start() is called, the calling thread will continue execution. When the timer interrupt is triggered, the specified callback function will be called. The timer will not generate another interrupt unless Timer_start() is called again. Calling Timer_stop() or Timer_close() after Timer_start() but, before the timer interrupt, will prevent the specified callback from ever being invoked.

Is a blocking call. A semaphore is used to block the calling thread's execution until the timer generates an interrupt. If Timer_stop() is called, the calling thread will become unblockedimmediately. The behavior of the timer in this mode is similar to a sleep function.

Is a non-blocking call. After Timer_start() is called, the calling thread will continue execution. When the timer interrupt is triggered, the specified callback function will be called. The timer is automatically restarted and will continue to periodically generate interrupts until Timer_stop() is called.

Is a non-blocking call. After Timer_start() is called, the calling thread will continue execution. The timer will not generate an interrupt in this mode. The timer hardware will run until Timer_stop() is called.

briefdescription.para: Timer mode settings.

detaileddescription.para: This enum defines the timer modes that may be specified in Timer_Params.

The timer driver supports four modes of operation which may be specified in the Timer_Params. The device specific implementation may configure the timer peripheral as an up or down counter. In any case, Timer_getCount() will return a value characteristic of an up counter.
Period specified in micro seconds.
Period specified in hertz; interrupts per second.
Period specified in ticks or counts. Varies from board to board.

briefdescription.para: Timer period unit enum.

detaileddescription.para: This enum defines the units that may be specified for the period in Timer_Params. This unit has no effect with Timer_getCounts.

briefdescription.para: A handle that is returned from a Timer_open() call.
Timer callback function.

detaileddescription.para: User definable callback function prototype. The timer driver will call the defined function and pass in the timer driver's handle and the pointer to the user-specified the argument.

memberdef.definition: typedef int_fast16_t(* Timer_ControlFxn) (Timer_Handle handle, uint_fast16_t cmd, void *arg)
memberdef.name: Timer_ControlFxn

briefdescription.para: A function pointer to a driver specific implementation of Timer_control().
A function pointer to a driver specific implementation of Timer_close().
A function pointer to a driver specific implementation of Timer_getCount().
A function pointer to a driver specific implementation of Timer_init().
A function pointer to a driver specific implementation of Timer_open().

memberdef.definition: typedef int32_t(* Timer_SetPeriodFxn) (Timer_Handle handle, Timer_PeriodUnits periodUnits, uint32_t period)
memberdef.name: Timer_SetPeriodFxn

briefdescription.para: A function pointer to a driver specific implementation of Timer_setPeriod().
A function pointer to a driver specific implementation of Timer_start().
A function pointer to a driver specific implementation of Timer_stop().
Timer Global configuration.

detaileddescription.para: The Timer_Config structure contains a set of pointers used to characterize the timer driver implementation.
This structure needs to be defined before calling Timer_init() and it must not be changed thereafter.

briefdescription.para: Function to close a timer. The corresponding timer to the Timer_Handle becomes an available timer resource.
Function performs device specific features on a given Timer_Handle.

parameterdescription.para: A command value defined by the driver specific implementation.
A pointer to an optional R/W (read/write) argument that is accompanied with cmd.

briefdescription.para: Function to get the current count of a timer. The value returned represents timer counts. The value returned is always characteristic of an up counter. This is true even if the timer peripheral is counting down. Some device specific implementations may employ a prescaler in addition to this timer count.

simplesect.para: The current count of the timer in timer ticks.

briefdescription.para: Function to initialize a timer module. This function will go through all available hardware resources and mark them as "available".

simplesect.para: The Timer_config structure must exist and be persistent before this function can be called. This function must also be called before any other timer driver APIs.

briefdescription.para: Function to initialize a given timer peripheral specified by the index argument. The Timer_Params specifies which mode the timer will operate. The accuracy of the desired period is limited by the the clock. For example, a 100 MHz clock will have a tick resolution of 10 nanoseconds. This function takes care of timer resource allocation. If the particular timer is available to use, the timer driver owns it and returns a Timer_Handle.

parameterdescription.para: Logical peripheral number for the timer indexed into the Timer_config table.
Pointer to an parameter block, if NULL it will use default values.

simplesect.para: A Timer_Handle upon success or NULL. If the desired period results in overflow, or saturation, of the timer, NULL is returned. If the timer resource is already in use, NULL is returned.

briefdescription.para: Function to set the period of the timer module after it has been opened.

simplesect.para: Timer_open() has been called. It is also recommended Timer_stop() has been called on an already running timer before calling this API as the period is updated asynchronously.

parameterdescription.para: Timer_PeriodUnits of the desired period value.

briefdescription.para: Function to initialize the Timer_Params struct to its defaults.

detaileddescription.para:
params
A pointer to Timer_Params structure for initialization.
Defaults values are: timerMode = Timer_ONESHOT_BLOCKING periodUnit = Timer_PERIOD_COUNTS timerCallback = NULL period = (uint16_t) ~0

briefdescription.para: Function to start the timer.
Function to stop timer. If the timer is already stopped, this function has no effect.
Timer driver.

detaileddescription.para: The timer driver allows you to measure elapsed time with simple and portable APIs.This driver does not have PWM or capture functionalities. These functionalities are addressed in both the capture and PWM driver.

The timer driver also handles the general purpose timer resource allocation. For each driver that requires use of a general purpose timer, it calls Timer_open() to occupy the specified timer, and calls Timer_close() to release the occupied timer resource.
This documentation provides a basic usage summary and a set of examples in the form of commented code fragments. Detailed descriptions of the APIs are provided in subsequent sections.
The following example code opens a timer in continuous callback mode. The period is set to 1000 Hz.
Timer_init() must be called before any other timer APIs. This function calls the device implementation's timer initialization function, for each element of Timer_config[].
Refer to the Driver's Configuration section for driver configuration information.
